job_title: Residential Support Worker in Bebington, England
cons: Unsociable hours, difficult to get holiday leave in smaller houses

review_title: Another struggling social care provider who can't retain staff but is reluctant to change
pros:
The people you support are lovely & some staff & team leaders are supportive & great to work with. And there is always overtime as being short staffed is the norm I'm afraid. 
Meals are provided while on shift also.
cons:
Most care companies are currently in the same boat drastically under staffed, reliant on guilting what little staff they have left to work long hours for terrible pay or paying agency more than they would ever pay their actual employees. Autism together is no different, well they may be worse actually as they are proposing a £9.50 p/h salary (like everyone will have from April 2022) but you can have it now aslong as you give them 5 of your holidays for it!
There seems to be no respect for the crucial work that you do by upper management only the bottom line counts. You think they would value & care for their employees & their industry but they just want to take from you while you are in one of the lowest paid but desperately needed jobs.
There are no shadow shifts generally due to short staffing, no opportunity for progression, no extra pay for nvq's, they steal your £1.00 -£1.50 over time rate by changing contracted hours, aswell as wanting to steal your holidays!
unsuitable hours sometimes but generally good

review_title: Taken a turn for the worst
job_title: Residential Support Worker in Bromborough, England
pros: Opportunity to learn more about autism, a fascinating disorder. No shortage of jobs. The clients love talking to you and you get to see their progress on a day-to-day basis.
cons: Clique atmosphere, especially in Oak House. Some of the office staff are very rude and condescending, particularly to autistic clients on placement there. No understanding of organisational function, little accountability. Bullying is rife. Pay is low. Communication between different houses is very poor. In the COVID situation, some have taken very lax approaches to the pandemic, leaving clients (who are physically vulnerable) at severe risk. An overrelaynce on underpaid staff to raise funds for the 'charity' as well as work long hours.
